questiontext.text:
Example

Find all the values of \(8^{1/3}\).

Solution

Using polar form

Solving \({z=8^{1/3}}\) for \(z\) is equivalent to solving the cubic equation \(z^3-8=0\). We expect that there are three possible values of \(z\) satisfying this cubic equation. Thus, rearranging: \(z^3=8\). Now write the right-hand side as a complex number in polar form: \[\qquad z^3=8(\cos 0+i\sin 0)\](i.e. \(r=|8|=8\) and arg(8)=0). However, if we now generalise our expression for the argument by adding an arbitrary integer multiple of \(2\pi\), we obtain the modified expression: \[z^3=8(\cos(2k\pi)+i\sin(2k\pi))\qquad k=0,\pm1,\pm2,\ldots\] Now take the cube root of both sides: \[\begin{aligned} z&=\root 3\of{8}(\cos (2k\pi )+i\sin (2k\pi ))^{1/3}\\ &=\root 3\of{8}\left(\cos\left(2k\pi\over 3\right)+i\sin\left(2k\pi\over 3\right)\right), \end{aligned}\] 

by applying De Moivre's theorem.

Now in this expression \(k\) can take any integer value including zero. The normal procedure is to take three consecutive values of \(k\) (say \(k=0,1,2\)). Any other value of \(k\) chosen will lead to a root (a value of \(z\)) which repeats one of the three already determined. \[\begin{aligned} \text{So if}\qquad k&=0\qquad z_0=2(\cos 0+i\sin 0)=2\\k&=1\qquad z_1=2\left(\cos {2\pi \over 3}+i\sin {2\pi\over 3}\right)=-1+i\sqrt{3}\\ k&=2\qquad z_2=2\left(\cos {4\pi \over 3}+i\sin {4\pi\over 3}\right)=-1-i\sqrt{3}\end{aligned}\] These are the three (complex) values of \(8^{1/3}\). The reader should verify, by direct multiplication, that \((-1+i\sqrt{3})^3=8\) and that \((-1-i\sqrt{3})^3=8\).

The reader may have noticed within this Example a subtle change in notation. When, for example, we write \(8^{1/3}\) then we are expecting three possible values, as calculated above. However, when we write \(\root 3\of {8}\) then we are only expecting one value: that delivered by your calculator.

Note the two complex roots are complex conjugates (since \(z^3-8=0\) is a polynomial equation with real coefficients).

Using exponential form

Precisely the same calculation can be carried through using the exponential form of a complex number. We take this opportunity to repeat this previous calculation but working exclusively in exponential form.

Thus \[\begin{aligned} z^3 &=8 \\ &=8e^{i (0)}\qquad\text{(i.e. } r=|8|=8\quad \text{and}\quad \text{arg}(8)=0) \\ &=8e^{i (2k\pi )}\qquad k=0,\pm1,\pm2,\ldots\end{aligned}\] therefore taking cube roots \[\begin{aligned} z&=\root 3\of{8}\left[e^{i (2k\pi )}\right]^{1/3} \\ &=\root 3\of{8}e^{i 2k\pi/3} \end{aligned}\]

using De Moivre's theorem.

Again \(k\) can take any integer value or zero. Any three consecutive values will give the roots. \[\begin{aligned} \text{So if}\qquad k&=0\qquad z_0=2e^{i 0}=2 \\ k&=1\qquad z_1=2e^{i 2\pi/3}=-1+i\sqrt{3}\\ k&=2\qquad z_2=2e^{i 4\pi/3}=-1-i\sqrt{3}\end{aligned}\]These are the three (complex) values of \(8^{1/3}\) obtained using the exponential form. Of course at the end of the calculation we have converted back to standard Cartesian form.
